column1: Birkenhead () is a town in the Metropolitan Borough of Wirral
column2: Merseyside
column3: England; historically
column4: until 1974
column5: in Cheshire. It is on the Wirral Peninsula
column6: along the south bank of the River Mersey
column7: opposite the city of Liverpool.  At the 2011 census
column9: 818.Birkenhead Priory and the Mersey Ferry were established in the 12th century. In the 19th century
column10: Birkenhead expanded greatly as a consequence of the Industrial Revolution. Birkenhead Park and Hamilton Square were laid out as well as the first street tramway in Britain. The Mersey Railway connected Birkenhead and Liverpool
column11: with the world's first tunnel beneath a tidal estuary
column12: and the shipbuilding firm Cammell Laird and a seaport were established.

column1: In the second half of the 20th century
column2: the town suffered a significant period of decline
column3: with containerisation causing a reduction in port activity. The Wirral Waters development is planned to regenerate much of the dockland.

column1: The name Birkenhead probably means "headland overgrown with birch"
column2: from the Old English bircen meaning birch tree
column3: of which many once grew on the headland which jutted into the river at Woodside. The name is not derived from the Birket
column4: a stream which enters the Mersey between Birkenhead and Seacombe. The Birket is a later name which was introduced by Ordnance Survey.

column1: The earliest records state that the Mersey ferry began operating from Birkenhead in 1150
column2: when Benedictine monks under the leadership of Hamon de Mascy built a priory there. The priory was visited in 1275 and 1277 by Edward I. In a royal charter of 13 April 1330
column3: Edward III granted the priory further rights.

column1: Distanced from the Industrial Revolution in Liverpool by the physical barrier of the River Mersey
column2: Birkenhead retained its agricultural status until the advent of steam ferry services. In 1817 a steam ferry service started from Liverpool to Tranmere and in 1822 the paddle steamer
column3: Royal Mail
column4: began operation between Liverpool and Woodside.Shipbuilding started in 1829. An iron works was initially established by William Laird in 1824 and was joined by his son John Laird in 1828. The business eventually became Cammell Laird. Notable naval vessels built at Birkenhead include HMS Achilles
column5: HMS Affray
column6: CSS Alabama
column7: HMS Ark Royal
column12: HMS Thetis (which sank in Liverpool Bay during sea trials
column13: and was refloated and commissioned as HMS Thunderbolt
column14: only to be lost to enemy action with the loss of the entire crew)
column15: HMS Conqueror and HMS Prince of Wales. Merchant vessels were also built such as RMS Mauretania and RMS Windsor Castle.

column1: In 1833 an act was passed to introduce street paving
column2: lighting and other improvements in the town. These included establishing a market and regulating the police force.The Mersey Railway tunnel opened in 1886
column3: providing direct railway access to Liverpool.

column1: The Grange Road West drill hall was completed in 1900.In September 1932 thousands of unemployed people protested in a series of demonstrations organised by the local branch of the National Unemployed Workers Movement. After three days of rioting
column2: police were brought in from elsewhere to help quell the rioters.In addition to the ferries and the railway
column3: the Queensway road tunnel opened in 1934 and gave rapid access to Liverpool. This opened up the Wirral Peninsula for development
column4: and prompted further growth of Birkenhead as an industrial centre. Bolstered by migration from rural Cheshire
column5: southern

column2: the town's population had grown from 110 in 1801 to 110
column3: 912 one hundred years later and stood at 142
column4: 501 by 1951.Birkenhead was struck by an F0/T1 tornado on 23 November 1981
column5: as part of the record-breaking nationwide tornado outbreak on that day.

column1: Formerly a township in Bidston Parish of the Wirral Hundred
column2: Birkenhead was incorporated as a municipal borough in 1877
column3: and became a county borough with the passing of the Local Government Act 1888. The borough included the parish of Birkenhead St. Mary and the townships of Bidston
column4: Claughton with Grange
column5: Oxton
column6: Tranmere and part of Bebington
column7: later known as Rock Ferry.

column2: Prenton and Thingwall were added in 1928
column3: followed by Noctorum
column4: Upton and Woodchurch in 1933.Prior to 1 April 1974
column5: Birkenhead and the rest of the Wirral Peninsula were part of the county of Cheshire. The implementation of the Local Government Act 1972 caused Birkenhead to lose its county borough status. The town has since been administered as part of the Metropolitan Borough of Wirral
column6: in the metropolitan county of Merseyside.  The Birkenhead and Tranmere electoral ward had a population of 15
column7: 879 in 2011.The current Member of Parliament for Birkenhead is Mick Whitley.

column2: as defined by the Office for National Statistics
column3: includes Birkenhead
column4: Wallasey
column5: Bebington
column6: Ellesmere Port (which is outside the Metropolitan Borough of Wirral) and the contiguous built-up areas which link those towns. In the 2011 Census
column7: the area so defined had a total population of 325
column9: making it the 19th largest conurbation in England and Wales.

column1: Shipbuilding and ship repair has featured prominently in the local economy since the 19th century. Cammell Laird entered receivership in 2001. The shipyard was sold and became 'Northwestern Shiprepairers & Shipbuilders' (NS&S)
column2: which grew into a successful business specialising in ship repair and conversion
column3: including maintenance contracts for the Royal Fleet Auxiliary. In September 2007 NS&S acquired the rights to use the Cammell Laird name. The company was renamed 'Cammell Laird Shiprepairers & Shipbuilders' on 17 November 2008
column4: seeing the famous name return to Birkenhead after a seven-year hiatus. In 2010
column5: Cammell Laird secured a £50 million contract to construct the flight deck for HMS Queen Elizabeth
column6: the first of two Queen Elizabeth-class aircraft carriers. In 2015
column7: Cammell Laird was selected as the preferred bidder to construct RRS Sir David Attenborough

column1: Birkenhead Market was first established on what is now the site of Birkenhead Town Hall
column2: between Chester Street and Hamilton Street
column3: on 10 July 1835.

column1: An increase in the town's population by 1841 led to the opening on 11 July 1845 of a much expanded market on a larger site nearby. This market hall was built by Fox
column2: Henderson & Co
column3: who later built The Crystal Palace. Michael Marks
column4: of Marks & Spencer
column5: opened one of his first seven 'Penny Bazaar' stalls here during the 1880s. On 31 January 2018
column6: Marks & Spencer announced the closure of their store
column7: in the town centre of Birkenhead
column9: the commercial centre of the town was redeveloped around the principal shopping area of Grange Road. Following two fires at the expanded Birkenhead Market in 1969 and 1974
column10: it was moved to new premises adjoining the Grange Shopping Precinct development in 1977. Commercial expansion continued in the early 1990s when the Pyramids Shopping Centre was opened.  The previous market site has been redeveloped with the construction of two office buildings
column11: primarily to house Land Registry and Department for Work and Pensions offices.

column2: the town had an overall unemployment rate of 8.2% (males 12.4%
column3: female 4.1%) as against a national average of 4.4%.

column2: Birkenhead had a population of 88
column3: 818. The wider Urban Subdivision had a population of over 142

column5: this latter figure includes areas such as Greasby and Frankby

column1: These are the 2011 ethnic groups for the town:
Birkenhead Park is acknowledged to be the first publicly funded park in Britain.
The park was the forerunner of the Parks Movement and its influence was far reaching both in Britain and abroad – most notably on Frederick Law Olmsted's design for Central Park.
Designed by Joseph Paxton (later Sir Joseph Paxton) in 1843 and officially opened in 1847
column2: with great festivity. The park's Grand Entrance
column3: modelled on the Temple of Illysus in Athens
column4: and its 'Roman Boathouse' are notable features. There are sandstone lodges at the three entrances
column5: each with a different style of architecture
column6: Gothic
column7: Norman and Italianate. There are also two lakes and an ornate 'Swiss Bridge'.

column2: a Scot
column3: and his son John
column4: were influential in the design of the town. Parts were laid out in a grid-iron pattern like Edinburgh New Town with similar architecture. The chief architect was James Gillespie Graham from Edinburgh. This grid pattern was centred around Hamilton Square which was started in 1826 and
column5: apart from Trafalgar Square in London
column6: contains the most Grade I listed buildings in one place in England. including Birkenhead Town Hall. A short distance from Hamilton Square are two other notable landmarks: the Queensway Tunnel Main Entrance and the Woodside Ferry Terminal. The film Chariots of Fire had scenes shot at Woodside. These scenes were as a representation of Dover in the 1920s.Other notable landmarks include Bidston Windmill on a ridge behind the town
column7: Flaybrick Watertower and Birkenhead Priory & St. Mary's Tower.

column1: Birkenhead had the first street tramway in Britain. Opened on 29 August 1860 the first line ran from Woodside (adjoining the terminal of the Mersey Ferry) to Birkenhead Park. This early system was horse-drawn and was the brainchild of flamboyant American
column2: George Francis Train.

column1: A preserved tram was on display in the Woodside ferry terminal booking hall.
The system was later electrified and operated from 1901 as Birkenhead Corporation Tramways. Two replica trams
column2: imported from Hong Kong
column3: have been brought into service as part of a heritage tramway between Woodside and Wirral Transport Museum
column4: and Birkenhead Corporation Tramways Car No.20 is preserved on this line.

column1: Horse-drawn buses began operating in Birkenhead in 1848
column2: to be replaced with motor vehicles after the First World War.Present-day services are run by operators including Arriva and Stagecoach and coordinated by Merseytravel. Birkenhead bus station opened in 1996.

column1: National Express provides long-distance coach services to other UK cities
column2: with direct routes including London
column3: Glasgow
column4: Bangor and Newcastle.

column1: Birkenhead Bus Station serves the town of Birkenhead. It is adjacent to The Grange Shopping Centre and Birkenhead Market.
It has a total of eleven stands and incorporates a travel centre. The main bus operators at the station include Arriva North West
column2: Avon Buses and Stagecoach Merseyside & South Lancashire

column1: Bus services using the bus station operate around the town of Birkenhead
column2: throughout the Wirral
column3: and to the nearby city of Liverpool via the Queensway Tunnel. The station also has frequent services to as far away as Chester.

column2: when the Chester and Birkenhead Railway began services. Birkenhead Grange Lane railway station opened at the same time
column3: becoming the town's first terminus. Birkenhead Dock railway station opened in 1866
column4: as the eastern terminus of the Hoylake Railway. With the opening of the Woodside and Birkenhead Dock Street Tramway in 1873
column5: this station probably became the world's first tram to train interchange. In 1886 Birkenhead and Liverpool were linked by an underground railway system
column6: which today is part of the Merseyrail network.

column1: The major underground station in Birkenhead is Hamilton Square
column2: the nearest station to the ferry terminal. Hamilton Square station is linked to the "Liverpool Loop" of the Wirral Line
column3: which includes James Street
column4: Moorfields
column5: Liverpool Lime Street and Liverpool Central stations
column6: all of which are underground. Other stations located in Birkenhead include Birkenhead Central which is open but below ground level
column7: Green Lane which is below ground level
column9: Conway Park which is below ground level

column1: The Wirral Line from Birkenhead travels south to Chester and Ellesmere Port
column2: north to New Brighton and westwards
column3: across the Wirral Peninsula
column4: to West Kirby. The Borderlands Line leaves Bidston station
column5: in the north of Birkenhead and travels through the rural centre of Wirral
column6: ultimately leaving England near Shotton and terminating in Wrexham
column7: Wales.From 1878
column9: Birkenhead Woodside railway station was the town's mainline railway terminus. Originally located close to Woodside Ferry Terminal
column10: the site had been redeveloped as part of Cammell Lairds ship builders. Latterly the adjacent dry dock at Cammell Lairds was filled in and the whole area redeveloped to provide flats
column11: a bus depot and offices for HM Land Registry and Child Support Agency (CSA).

column1: The town has one operational railway depot
column2: Birkenhead North TMD; one disused
column3: Birkenhead Central TMD; and two demolished
column4: Birkenhead Mollington Street TMD and a further depot adjacent to Birkenhead Park station. The remains of the Birkenhead Dock Branch are still extant in a cutting through the centre of the town
column5: which was used primarily for freight services. Much of the peripheral railway infrastructure
column6: around the docks
column7: has been removed since the 1980s.

column1: Junctions 1 and 3 of the M53 motorway allow access to the national motorway network. The A41 trunk road connects Woodside with Marble Arch in London. Two road tunnels
column2: the Queensway road tunnel from Birkenhead
column3: and the Kingsway road tunnel from Wallasey
column4: run underneath the River Mersey and connect the town to Liverpool.

column1: Birkenhead's dock system is part of the Port of Liverpool
column2: operated by the Mersey Docks and Harbour Company under the ownership of The Peel Group. The Twelve Quays ferry terminal allows a direct freight and passenger vehicle service to Dublin
column3: Ireland and Belfast
column4: Northern Ireland. Daily Belfast services are run by Stena Line
column5: using their RoPax ferries MS Stena Lagan and MS Stena Mersey. The Mersey Ferry at Woodside operates a passenger service to Liverpool and chartered cruising.

column2: the Isle of Man Steam Packet Company operates a service from Birkenhead to Douglas using MS Ben-my-Chree. Due to weather conditions
column3: this service temporarily replaces the route that normally operates from the Liverpool landing stage using fast craft.

column1: The nearest airport is Liverpool John Lennon Airport (formerly known as Speke Airport) located about 8 miles (13 km) from Birkenhead. Manchester Airport is approximately 40 mi (64 km) from Birkenhead. Other nearby aviation facilities include Hawarden Airport and RAF Woodvale. Former airfields in the area include RAF Hooton Park and Bidston Aerodrome.
Birkenhead has a number of maintained schools
column2: including Birkenhead Park School (formed after the merger of Rock Ferry High School and Park High School) and the only all-boys Catholic grammar school in the area St. Anselm's College.

column1: Birkenhead also has two independently run schools. The oldest is Birkenhead School. It was exclusively a boys' school from its founding in 1860 until 2000
column2: when its sixth form became co-educational. It became fully co-educational for pupils aged 3–18 in 2008. "Old Birkonians" (as former pupils are known) include the lawyer F.E. Smith (Lord Birkenhead); Andreas Whittam Smith (chairman of the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) and founder of The Independent newspaper); Andrew Irvine
column3: and Philip Toosey
column4: hero at the Bridge on the River Kwai; and Tony Hall
column5: Director-General of the BBC.

column2: formerly Birkenhead Girls High School
column3: is an all-ability state funded girls' Academy. It was founded in 1885 and caters for girls aged 3–19. Its sponsor was the Girls' Day School Trust
column4: but is now publicly funded. Its alumnae include the actress Patricia Routledge. Birkenhead Girls High School decided to become a state-funded Academy school in 2009
column5: increasing the availability of its education. Like the change to co-education at Birkenhead School
column6: this decision was largely driven by falling pupil numbers; however to this date
column7: it remains a single sex school.

column1: Birkenhead Institute Grammar School existed from 1889 in Whetstone Lane
column2: before being moved to Claughton in the 1970s. The school closed in 1994. The school's alumni include Wilfred Owen.
Birkenhead's college has campuses at Europa Boulevard and Twelve Quays. The college was originally Birkenhead Technical College
column3: and has been known as Wirral Metropolitan College since the 1980s. The college had a theatre on Borough Road named after one of its most famous former students
column4: Glenda Jackson
column5: the Oscar-winning actress and Member of Parliament
column6: herself a Birkonian
column7: born in 1936. The Borough Road campus and the Glenda Jackson Theatre were demolished in late 2005
column9: although Wirral Metropolitan College flourishes on other sites across Wirral. The theatre secretly housed an emergency command centre for the region in its basement
column10: accessible via the college. Politicians and officials would have retreated to this secure bunker in the event of nuclear war to co-ordinate the recovery effort. By the 1990s
column11: after the end of the Cold War
column12: the bunker had been decommissioned and the surrounding complex of rooms was used by the college as a rehearsal space and recording studio.Other colleges include the Birkenhead Sixth Form College
column13: located in the Claughton area of Birkenhead
column14: formerly the site of Corpus Christi Catholic High School.

column1: Religion in Birkenhead dates back to 1150 when Hamon de Masci founded Birkenhead Priory for the Benedictine order.
The current Anglican churches are St. James' Church
column2: Christ Church and the Church of Christ the King which are all within the Diocese of Chester. Keith Sinclair is the suffragan Bishop of Birkenhead.

column1: Roman Catholic churches include the Church of Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception and St. Werburgh's Church which are within the Diocese of Shrewsbury.

The other religious buildings include the Wirral Christian Centre of the Elim Pentecostal Church and the Islamic Shah Jalal Mosque. The Jewish Birkenhead Synagogue existed from 1890 and closed prior to 2006.Flaybrick Memorial Gardens contains the town's former main cemetery
column2: which is situated near to St. James' Church. Flaybrick Hill Cemetery has been superseded by Landican Cemetery.

column1: Birkenhead has one of the highest mortality rates among men over 65 in the UK. Birkenhead is served by Wirral University Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust (through its Arrowe Park Hospital
column2: St Catherine's Health Centre and Clatterbridge Hospital sites) and Wirral Primary Care Trust. Formerly
column3: Birkenhead was also served by Birkenhead General Hospital on Park Road North and St. James' Hospital in Claughton
column4: now demolished and redeveloped for housing.

column1: The Laird School of Art was the first public school of art outside London and was given to the town by John Laird. It opened on 27 September 1871. The Williamson Art Gallery was opened in 1928 and houses a fine collection of paintings
column2: porcelain and pottery.
Birkenhead Library was opened as the country's first public library in an unincorporated borough.

column1: The library was situated in Hamilton Street until 1909
column2: when it moved to a new building in Market Street South
column3: near Birkenhead Market. In the 1930s
column4: this building (along with much of the surrounding area) was demolished to make way for the entrance to the Queensway Tunnel. The present library
column5: Birkenhead Central Library
column6: is situated on Borough Road and was opened by King George V in 1934.Despite being in England
column7: Birkenhead (known as Penbedw
column8: in Welsh) hosted Wales' National Eisteddfod in 1917 as well as an unofficial National Eisteddfod event in 1879. As in Liverpool
column11: contributed greatly to the growth of the town and its cultural development in the 19th century. The first local Birkenhead Eisteddfod
column12: a precursor of the national events
column13: took place in 1864. The 1917 National Eisteddfod was notable for the award of the chair to the poet Ellis Humphrey Evans
column14: known as Hedd Wyn. The winner was announced
column15: and the crowd waited for the winner to accept congratulations before the chairing ceremony
column16: but no winner appeared. It was then announced that Hedd Wyn had been killed the previous month on the battlefield in Belgium
column17: and the bardic chair was draped in black. These events were portrayed in the Academy Award nominated film Hedd Wyn
column18: and were apparently intended as a protest against the war policies of Prime Minister David Lloyd George
column19: who was present. There is a commemorative stone for the event in Birkenhead Park. The first meeting of the international Celtic Congress also took place at the Birkenhead Eisteddfod.The Argyle Theatre was a major theatre and music hall which opened on 28 December 1868 and became notable for the calibre of artistes who appeared there. Later in its life
column20: it was also used as a cinema. The theatre was destroyed by bombing in 1940.The Theatre Royal
column22: was in Argyle Street and had a capacity of 1
column23: 850. This theatre was closed in 1919 and demolished in the 1930s. Another theatre
column25: which was converted into a cinema in the 1930s
column26: stood on the site of what became the Co-operative department store in Grange Road.The Little Theatre was established in 1958 from a converted former Presbyterian church. The Pacific Road Arts Centre in Woodside opened in 1999
column27: but in 2015 was converted to a “Business Hub”.

column1: Birkenhead is served by the Liverpool Echo local daily newspaper. The free local weekly newspapers are the Wirral Globe and the Birkenhead News (part of the Wirral News group).
The local radio station Heart Wirral is based in offices at the Pacific Road Arts Centre. In addition
column2: there are five other local radio stations that transmit to Birkenhead: BBC Radio Merseyside
column3: Radio City 96.7
column4: Greatest Hits Liverpool
column5: Capital Liverpool and CityTalk.

column1: Birkenhead is situated within the television regions of BBC North West and ITV's Granada Television. The local television station Bay TV Liverpool also broadcasts to the area.

column2: other recreational open spaces in Birkenhead include Mersey Park and Victoria Park. Arrowe Park is a large area of parkland at the western edge of the town. In 1929
column3: the 3rd World Scout Jamboree was held there.

column1: The first two Boy Scout groups in the world are thought to have been founded as the 1st and 2nd Birkenhead groups at YMCA on the same night in 1908. The 2nd Birkenhead Scout Group is still operating and therefore is the longest running scout group in the world.
The first known football  club on the Wirral was Birkenhead F.C. which was founded in 1879 by Robert E. Lythgoe
column2: a former Druids F.C. player. Other clubs included Belmont Football Club
column3: founded in 1884.  They adopted the name Tranmere Rovers F.C. the following year
column4: and are a professional team who play at Prenton Park near the Tranmere area of the town. They were a founder member of Division Three North in 1921
column5: and were a member of The Football League until 2015
column6: when they were relegated to the Conference
column7: the fifth tier of English football. They returned to the Football League three seasons later
column8: after a 2-1 play off final win against Boreham Wood F.C..  (An unrelated
column9: disbanded side had played under the name "Tranmere Rovers Cricket Club (Association football section)" in 1881–82.) Cammell Laird 1907 F.C. is the town's semi-professional football club who play at Kirklands in Rock Ferry. They play in the North West Counties League Division One.

column1: The Birkenhead Park Football Club was founded in 1871
column2: the same year as the Rugby Football Union. The club originally played in the Lower Park but moved to their current home in the Upper Park in 1885. Birkenhead Park also has its own cricket club.Located in the town are the Birkenhead North End and Victoria Cycling Clubs. Olympic riders from the clubs include Chris Boardman
column3: Mark Bell
column4: Steve Cummings and Rachel Heal.Birkenhead has been host to various rowing clubs since 1840. At present
column5: Liverpool Victoria Rowing Club operates from a facility at the western end of West Float.

column1: Birkenhead is mentioned in the song "What She Said" on the album Meat Is Murder by the Smiths: What she read/All heady books/She'd sit and prophesise/(It took a tattooed boy from Birkenhead/To really really open her eyes).
The town is also referred to in the song "Everything Is Sorrow" on the Boo Radleys' C'mon Kids album: I worked in Birkenhead for you/It brings me tears even now.
A fairly detailed description of the town is given in Paul O'Grady's memoirs
column2: At My Mother's Knee... and Other Low Joints: The Autobiography.

column1: The major redevelopment project under consideration is Peel Holdings' "Wirral Waters". This would allow for £4.5 billion of investment in the regeneration of the dockland area. This equates with an investment of over £14
column2: 000 for each of the 320
column3: 000 residents of the Wirral. At the East Float and Vittoria Dock
column4: the development would include several 50-storey skyscrapers
column7: 000 square feet (465
column8: 000 m2) of new office space and 11
column12: 000 m2) for new residential flats. A retail and leisure quarter at the former Bidston Dock site would encompass another 571
column14: 000 m2) of space. The whole project would create more than 27
column16: aside from the employment required for construction and other peripheral employment. The development would be expected to take up to thirty years.
